title: 111_hr3703
content:
The Act may be cited as the "White House Conference on Autism Act of 2009". Key findings are also included in the Act. The Congress finds that Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASD) are the fastest-growing developmental disability in the U.S., with rates increasing significantly. The epidemic of autism is costly, with a new case diagnosed every 20 minutes, surpassing diagnoses of AIDS, diabetes, and cancer combined. The nation is ill-equipped to handle the impact of autism on education, labor, housing, and medical services. Autism is a life-changing condition that is expected to increase significantly in the next decade. The nation is ill-equipped to handle the impact of autism on education, labor, housing, and medical services. The autism epidemic could potentially deprive the nation of future talent in various fields. Despite being an urgent societal concern, autism research receives less than 5 percent of federal funding compared to other childhood diseases. The Combating Autism Act of 2006 committed nearly $1 billion to autism research. The "Combating Autism Act of 2006" allocated almost $1 billion for autism research, focusing on environmental factors, treatments, early identification, and support services. A White House Conference on Autism aims to further advance research on cutting-edge treatments and services for autism. SEC. 3. AUTHORIZATION OF THE CONFERENCE. The White House Conference on Autism, to be convened by the President by December 31, 2010, aims to combat the autism epidemic in the US. The Secretaries of Health and Human Services, Education, and Housing and Urban Development will plan and conduct the Conference to find the causes of autism, provide solutions and services for autistic individuals and families, and engage scientific experts in addressing the challenges faced. The White House Conference on Autism, scheduled by December 31, 2010, aims to address the causes of autism, provide solutions and services for autistic individuals and families, engage scientific experts in research, and review existing legislation and programs at all levels. The White House Conference on Autism, scheduled by December 31, 2010, aims to review existing legislation and programs at all levels to improve services for autistic individuals and their families. Recommendations for legislative action will be developed to enhance the health and well-being of autistic individuals. The policy committee and related committees are established. Established by June 30, 2009, the Policy Committee consists of 17 members appointed by the President, House Speaker, House minority leader, and Senate. Members include officers or employees of the United States and individuals experienced in addressing autism spectrum disorders. The Policy Committee, established by June 30, 2009, consists of 17 members appointed by various leaders. Two members are selected by the House minority leader and Senate minority leader, with specific qualifications required for some members. The Policy Committee, established by June 30, 2009, consists of 17 members appointed by various leaders. Members must have specific qualifications, including knowledge about autism intervention programs, educational and housing needs of individuals with autism, training for law enforcement, and environmental factors related to autism development. The Policy Committee, established in 2009, consists of 17 members with specific qualifications. One member must be knowledgeable about environmental or toxic exposure in relation to autism development. The Surgeon General serves as the chairperson, with voting by majority and the chairperson breaking tie votes. The Committee's duties include making recommendations for the timely convening of the Conference. The Policy Committee, chaired by the Surgeon General, makes recommendations for the Conference agenda, delegates, delegate selection, and an executive committee. SEC. 5. CONFERENCE DELEGATES.

The Cochairs will gather delegates from various backgrounds related to autism and neurodevelopmental disorders, including government representatives, professionals, laypeople, and members of the public affected by autism spectrum disorders in the United States. In administering this section, the Cochairs shall provide notice to Policy Committee members of meetings, request cooperation from other federal departments, make proposed agendas public, provide background materials, and hire additional personnel as needed. The Cochairs may employ additional personnel as needed to carry out the provisions of the Act without following standard appointment procedures. They must ensure that the proposed agenda is published in the Federal Register within 30 days of approval, personnel are balanced in viewpoints, and recommendations are not influenced inappropriately. The Cochairs of the Conference may accept gifts to support the provisions of the Act, including cash, in-kind donations, and voluntary services. These gifts are intended to assist in carrying out the Conference's objectives. The Cochairs of the Conference can accept gifts, including cash or in-kind donations, to support the provisions of the Act. These gifts are available to carry out the Act and must be recorded, including the sources, amounts, and uses of the gifts accepted. SEC. 7. REPORT OF THE CONFERENCE. The Policy Committee will prepare a preliminary report on the Conference within 100 days of adjournment, to be published in the Federal Register and sent to state CEOs. A final report, including state CEOs' views, will be prepared within 6 months and submitted to the President and Congress. SEC. 8. STATUS REPORTS. SEC. 8. STATUS REPORTS. The Surgeon General will prepare and publish status reports on the implementation of recommendations every 2 years after the Conference adjourns. The Comptroller General will do the same every 5 years until all recommendations are achieved. SEC. 9. DEFINITION OF STATE. The term "State" in this Act refers to several States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Guam, American Samoa, the Virgin Islands, or the Northern Mariana Islands. SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization is granted for necessary appropriations to carry out the Act, with limitations on new spending authority. Funds appropriated or received as gifts shall remain available for a year after the Conference adjourns. Funds under section 6(c) must be spent within 1 year after the Conference adjourns. Any unspent funds will be returned to the Treasury, unless a trust fund is established for a future Conference on Autism if the Conference is not convened before December 31, 2010.
